item.title: The Last Caretaker’s ‘Final Frontier’ Update Adds New Vehicle, Locations, and More
item.content:encoded:
The Last Caretaker is currently unfolding in early access and impressing gamers worldwide. It’s an ambitious, emotional game that presents players with the utmost freedom, sending them into a world devastated by rising oceans and tasking them with preserving the remnants of humanity, hundreds of years after they’ve left the planet.

Channel37, the game’s developer, has just unveiled the bulk of The Final Frontier, the game’s second major update since it was released in December 2025 in early access. It’s fairly accurate to say this update is huge.

New Ways to Sail, New Places to Sail To

The Final Frontier has just been released, marking the arrival of the second major expansion to The Last Caretaker. Despite the name, it’s just the beginning for this open-world sandbox, which we recently awarded a 9/10 in our full review.

The update starts with new ways to explore the game. Players are tasked with finding a new location, ‘Rocky Islands’, which leads to them unlocking the CS-17 Courier Skimmer, a Jet Ski-type craft. This is contained within a whole new biome that itself contains more quests to uncover.

Additionally, Channel37 has added ‘The Maze’, a tricky facility that’s not hard to find, but is hard to escape from once you’re lost within. That, too, contains more quest lines to discover.

The order of the day with The Final Frontier is deeper customization, and with that in mind, players can tweak their all-important vessel with 37 paint styles, all of which are free to find around the world. Additionally, new tools, such as the ‘deep ocean floor sonar’, have been added.

Channel37 has introduced a stack of quality-of-life improvements and adjustments with The Final Frontier, including:

  • Better building visualization and snapping
  • New dismantling visuals per material
  • Animation and usability improvements
  • Improved underwater visibility
  • More data logs to find
  • New achievements
  • Performance and stability upgrades across physics, rendering, buoyancy, cables, and UI

The Final Frontier is totally free to download and explore, and it represents the second in a very long line of updates planned for The Last Caretaker.

item.title: Mattel acquires control of mobile studio Mattel163 from NetEase
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 11, 2026

1 Min Read

Global toy and entertainment company, Mattel, has acquired full ownership of mobile game studio Mattel163 from Chinese conglomerate NetEase.

In a note to investors, Mattel said the deal values Mattel163 at $318 million—with the company handing over $159 million to NetEase for its 50 percent stake.

Mattel163 has worked on titles such as Uno!, Uno Wonder, Phase 10, and Skip Bo. Collectively, the studio's video game slate has amassed over 550 million downloads worldwide and approximately 20 million monthly active users. 

Mattel, which owns major brands such as Barbie, Polly Pocket, Hot Wheels, and Thomas & Friends, said the deal will meaningfully advance its digital game business through the addition of significant development, publishing, and digital customer acquisition expertise. 

The U.S. company now intends to increase its mobile game output and "enhance alignment" with its broader product roadmap.

Related:Pacific Drive developer Ironwood Studios raises $4 million in seed funding

"Integrating Mattel163 with Mattel’s digital business will create scale benefits in performance marketing and cross promotion, as well as greater synergy with Mattel brand marketing. The acquisition is in line with Mattel’s strategy to capture the full value of its IP in high-margin, highly accretive entertainment verticals," explained the company in a statement. 

Mattel CEO and chairman, Ynon Kreiz, said the company wants to create video games to "extend physical play to the virtual world." 

"The Mattel163 team has done remarkably well building this business from the ground up and we look forward to welcoming them on board," he added. "Our portfolio of iconic brands lends itself perfectly to the digital world and the acquisition will strengthen our position and accelerate our presence in a large, high-growth market."
